interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Review Date: 2015/03/14
Average Rating: 4.9
Product Details: {'Content advisory': ['Nudity', 'violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Adam Arkin', 'Jon Avnet', 'Peter Werner', 'Michael Dinner', 'John Dahl', 'Bill Johnson', 'Michael W. Watkins', 'Gwyneth Horder-Payton', 'Don Kurt', 'Dean Parisot'], 'Producers': ['Graham Yost', 'Elmore Leonard', 'Michael Dinner', 'Sarah Timberman', 'Carl Beverly'], 'Starring': ['Timothy Olyphant', 'Nick Searcy', 'Jere Burns'], 'Studio': ['FX Cable Channel']}
Review Text: Except for Raylan and his fellow law-enforcement professionals, almost everyone on this show is bad. They do evil, despicable things, which the creators of Justified have no qualms about showing us in graphic detail. A part of me feels guilty for loving such a lurid show, and that's the only reason I don't give Justified five stars. But the characters, even the bad ones, are so *interesting,* and then, of course, there's Raylan Givens and Boyd Crowder. I'm a straight guy, but I think Tim Olyphant's Raylan Givens is one sexy male TV character.
Review Title: Guilty pleasure
Rating: 4.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
{'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English', 'English [Audio Description]', 'हिन्दी', 'मराठी', 'తెలుగు', 'Français', 'தமிழ்'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]', 'Français', 'हिन्दी', 'Indonesia', '한국어', 'Bahasa Melayu', 'ไทย', 'Tiếng Việt', '中文（简体）'], 'Directors': ['Gary Ross'], 'Producers': ['Nina Jacobson', 'Jon Kilik'], 'Starring': ['Jennifer Lawrence', 'Josh Hutcherson', 'Liam Hemsworth'], 'Studio': ['SciFi and Fantasy']} The main reason I read the HG trilogy is because I had seen "Winter's Bone" in theaters when it was first released, and I thought Jennifer Lawrence was an amazing actress. When I learned that she was going to play the lead in The Hunger Games, I knew I'd want to see the movie. Fortunately, I've enjoyed reading speculative fiction all of my life, so it was no stretch for me to read THG. I have a problem with the basic premise -- that a totalitarian government would be able to take its citizens' children away from them to fight in gladiatorial combat. I don't believe in real life that people would put up with it. There would surely have been a revolution long before 74 years of Hunger Games competition had passed. That said, I set aside my disbelief as best I could while reading the books and watching the movie. The books aren't literary fiction, but they were entertaining and interesting enough to keep me engaged, mostly to find out what happens to Katniss.

I thought the movie was faithful enough to the first book in the series, and the video and audio quality of this Blu-Ray disc is excellent, about what I'd expect. All of the performances were very good, and, as I expected, Jennifer Lawrence was outstanding. She's one of the greatest young actresses of our time, and I'm sure she'll have a highly successful career. I wasn't crazy about the jerky, handheld camera movements, but I got used to it, and I understand the director's rationale for using it. Actually he explained it well in the disc's extras. I enjoyed the behind-the-scenes documentary about the making of the movie, although I thought it felt at times as if they were trying to justify their creative choices to appease Hunger Games geeks. I know there were people who were frustrated at the various ways the movie didn't precisely follow the book, and who thought Jennifer Lawrence was a bad choice to play Katniss. I can't imagine another actress in the role of Katniss Everdeen. Hunger Games is good. Jennifer Lawrence is awesome. {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Adam Arkin', 'Jon Avnet', 'Peter Werner', 'Michael Dinner', 'John Dahl', 'Bill Johnson', 'Michael W. Watkins', 'Gwyneth Horder-Payton', 'Don Kurt', 'Dean Parisot'], 'Producers': ['Sarah Timberman', 'Carl Beverly', 'Michael Dinner', 'Graham Yost', 'Elmore Leonard'], 'Studio': ['FX Cable Channel']} I don't know if the character was written specifically for Tim Olyphant, but I can't imagine anyone else playing Raylan Givens, and Olyphant plays Raylan perfectly. This show has everything I like: great, character-driven stories, suspense, romance, action, comedy, you-name-it. In my opinion, Justified couldn’t exist without Raylan Givens, but almost as important is Walton Goggins' Boyd Crowder. I love the chemistry between these two charismatic men, and the fact that the line between good and evil is blurry. It's shows like Justified that make me occasionally fantasize buying a cable subscription. Timothy Olyphant is Raylan Givens {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Jack Bender', 'Peter Leto', 'David Barrett', 'Sergio Mimica-Gezzan', 'Kari Skogland', 'Eriq La Salle', 'Edward Ornelas', 'Peter Weller', 'Roxann Dawson', 'Paul A. Edwards'], 'Starring': ['Mike Vogel', 'Rachelle Lefevre', 'Natalie Martinez'], 'Studio': ['CBS']} I watched several episodes hoping it would get better, but it was too contrived, formulaic, and inconsistent for me. It wasn’t awful, just mediocre-or-worse, and I've seen variations of it all in much-better TV shows and/or movies. Standard TV Series Quality Pacific Rim [Blu-ray] Idris Elba (Actor), Charlie Hunnam (Actor), Guillermo del Toro (Director) & 0 more Rated: PG-13 Format: Blu-ray Movies & TV, Blu-ray, Movies {'Genre': 'Science Fiction & Fantasy, Action & Adventure', 'Format': 'Blu-ray, DTS Surround Sound, Dolby, Color, Digital Sound', 'Contributor': 'Guillermo del Toro, Burn Gorman, Idris Elba, Diego Klattenhoff, Max Martini, Charlie Hunnam, Rinko Kikuchi, Charlie DayGuillermo del Toro, Burn Gorman, Idris Elba, Diego Klattenhoff, Max Martini, Charlie Hunnam, Rinko Kikuchi, Charlie Day See more', 'Language': 'English (Dolby Digital 5.1), Spanish (Dolby Digital 5.1)', 'Studio': 'WarnerBrothers', 'Aspect Ratio': '1.85:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG-13 (Parents Strongly Cautioned)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 2.4 Ounces', 'Item model number': '27605068', 'Director': 'Guillermo del Toro', 'Media Format': 'Blu-ray, DTS Surround Sound, Dolby, Color, Digital Sound', 'Release date': 'October 15, 2013', 'Actors': 'Idris Elba, Charlie Hunnam, Diego Klattenhoff, Rinko Kikuchi, Charlie Day', 'Dubbed': 'French, Spanish', 'Subtitles': 'Spanish, English, French, Portuguese', 'Number of discs': '2'} I enjoyed Godzilla, Rodan, Mothra, and other cheesy Japanese monster movies when I was a kid, but none of them could hold a candle to Pacific Rim. Pacific Rim is immensely fun and exciting, and there's a bit of a human-interest subplot that develops between the Kaiju-Jaeger battles. The visuals and effects are awesome. This is lightweight sci-fi action movie, nothing more, and for me it was totally satisfying. What "Godzilla" dreamed of being... Justified Suspense, Western, Drama, Action ["Deputy US Marshal Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) will start to pick at the thread of a cold case over 30 years in the making, unraveling a riddle that echoes all the way back to his boyhood and his criminal father's bad dealings. Meanwhile, Boyd Crowder (Walton Goggins) finds his grip on Harlan loosening due to a Pentecostal preacher with a penchant for theatrics and a knack for manipulation..."] {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Adam Arkin', 'Jon Avnet', 'Peter Werner', 'Michael Dinner', 'John Dahl', 'Bill Johnson', 'Michael W. Watkins', 'Gwyneth Horder-Payton', 'Don Kurt', 'Dean Parisot'], 'Producers': ['Fred Golan', 'Sarah Timberman', 'Carl Beverly', 'Michael Dinner', 'Graham Yost', 'Elmore Leonard']} I watch Justified for the characters and the stories. It's dark (but not too dark), suspenseful, and sometimes funny. I think of the funny parts as comic relief, because generally there's a lot of tension, and I'm always in suspense to see who gets killed or beaten next. I especially love the chemistry between Raylan Givens (Timothy Olyphant) and Boyd Crowder (Walton Goggins), but even the supporting characters are richly drawn, and it's fascinating watching all these law enforcers and criminals from another culture. Justified feels like an old western set in contemporary times. Juicy, character-driven series {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Paul Michael Glaser'], 'Producers': ['George Linder', 'Tim Zinnemann', 'Keith Barish', 'Rob Cohen'], 'Starring': ['Arnold Schwarzenegger', 'Maria Conchita Alonso', 'Yaphet Kotto']} Sometimes I don't mind watching bad movies. I'd already seen this when it was first released, years ago, and at the time I had enjoyed it, more-or-less. Now I wonder what I liked about the movie when I first saw it. The concept is interesting, and with good writing, acting, and directing, this could have been a good movie. It's okay if you're in the mood for a mindless, cheesy, cornball, action movie, and you don't mind terrible acting and dialog that sounds like it was written by a 13-year-old high school dropout. About as subtle as a week-old skunk roadkill in the middle of July {'Content advisory': ['Violence', 'alcohol use', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English Dialogue Boost: High', 'English', 'English Dialogue Boost: Medium'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Michael Nankin', 'Allan Kroeker', 'Andy Wolk', 'Allan Arkush', 'Larry Shaw', 'Omar Madha', 'Scott Stewart', 'Mairzee Almas', 'Félix Enríquez Alcalá', 'Todd Slavkin'], 'Starring': ['Grant Bowler', 'Julie Benz', 'Tony Curran'], 'Studio': ['Syfy']} It's not must-see TV, but if you're into SF, it's a mildly entertaining, if occasionally cheesy and predictable, diversion. One of the problems I have with shows like Defiance is that the "aliens" are all-too-human, in appearance and behavior. Star Trek was like this too. When I'm watching Defiance, I can't help but think of Firefly, which, like Defiance, gives us a civilization employing old and new technology. But for me, Firefly was a fresher, more engaging show, with great characters. Watching Defiance makes me wish Joss Whedon would resurrect Firefly. Good, not great, SF adventure series {'Content advisory': ['Nudity', 'violence', 'substance use', 'alcohol use', 'smoking', 'foul language', 'sexual content'], 'Audio languages': ['English'], 'Subtitles': ['English [CC]'], 'Directors': ['Adam Arkin', 'Jon Avnet', 'Peter Werner', 'Michael Dinner', 'John Dahl', 'Bill Johnson', 'Michael W. Watkins', 'Gwyneth Horder-Payton', 'Don Kurt', 'Dean Parisot'], 'Producers': ['Graham Yost', 'Elmore Leonard', 'Michael Dinner', 'Sarah Timberman', 'Carl Beverly'], 'Starring': ['Timothy Olyphant', 'Nick Searcy', 'Jere Burns'], 'Studio': ['FX Cable Channel']} Except for Raylan and his fellow law-enforcement professionals, almost everyone on this show is bad. They do evil, despicable things, which the creators of Justified have no qualms about showing us in graphic detail. A part of me feels guilty for loving such a lurid show, and that's the only reason I don't give Justified five stars. But the characters, even the bad ones, are so *interesting,* and then, of course, there's Raylan Givens and Boyd Crowder. I'm a straight guy, but I think Tim Olyphant's Raylan Givens is one sexy male TV character. Guilty pleasure
profile:
**Updated User Profile Summary:**

- **Genres:** The user continues to have a strong enthusiasm for speculative fiction and fantasy, with an appreciation for character-driven dramas in suspense and westerns, showcasing a blend of darker themes and light-hearted elements.

- **Key Interests:** They remain drawn to media adaptations that feature skilled performances, innovative storytelling, and high production quality, while valuing explorations of human behavior within diverse cultural contexts.

- **Themes:** Emotional depth and complex moral dilemmas are significant, alongside well-crafted narratives that balance tension with humor. The user has demonstrated a growing acceptance of entertaining yet predictable content, emphasizing enjoyment even in flawed narratives.

- **Viewing Experience:** A priority for high-quality audiovisual content persists, and while they favor original storytelling, their tolerance for less compelling narratives when entertainment value is present has increased.

- **Engagement:** The user connects deeply with character arcs and dynamics, expressing enjoyment for complex characters, including morally ambiguous figures. Rich interactions and suspenseful plots are crucial to their viewing pleasure.

- **Rating Patterns:** They maintain a tendency to rate positively but remain discerning about originality and execution. Their taste balances deeper narratives with entertaining escapism, acknowledging varying audience trends.

- **Community Insights:** The user advocates for strong narratives and meaningful performances, showcasing a versatile taste that appreciates both highbrow and accessible storytelling, with an openness to finding value in guilty pleasures.
